div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,596] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Throw Steel Nibs Away!
div.p: They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Commencing October 1st the steamers are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 October. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather remains cool and fine with rather chilly nights. An easterly wind still prevails, and through the barometer is falling slightly there is little indication of any change.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1906.
The Plague.
To-day’s plague bulletin reports the admission to hospital of an Armenian of the Menshieb quarter.
Chrysanthemum Show.
The Alexandria Horticultural Society will hold their annual Chrysanthemum Show at San Stefano on Saturday next.
Land and Mortgage Co.
The numbers are announced of 44 Four and a Half per cent. Debentures, amounting to £ 1,4' 0, which have been drawn for paymen at par on Nov. 12.
The Legislative Council.
It is reported that two new permanent numbers will be appointed shortly to succeed the late Mohamed Abdon and Abdel Khalik el Saadat on the Legislative Council.
The Rise in Land.
Cairo building land has risen a further 50 % in price, reports the “Mokattam.” This is due to the growing population and the inadequate accommodation therefor.
The Cotton Harvest.

At a harvest thanksgiving service at a church in Blackburn, Lancashire, recently, the vicar mindful of the staple trade of the district, made it a celebration of the cotton harvest, and cotton pods, etc. were used for the decoration of the church.
Arrest of a Thief.

The police of Zigszig. acting on telegraphic instructions from Suez, have arrested a European who had fled thither with two Credit Foncier Egyptien shares, which he had stolen from a comrade of his at Suez. He is now under arrest, thanks to the prompt action of Saghcolaghassi De Turris, moawin of police of Suez.
The Shoubra Crime.

A further enquiry into this now mysterious affair has been ordered by M. de Reffye, in consequence of revelations which tend to inculpate the bowabs of the Maison Ciccolani. Peillard father and son have been acquitted, though facts and circumstances were strongly against at least the son.
Suez Canal.

On the 26th October, 12 vessels, of which 8 were northward and 4 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 361,238.92. Of these 7 were British, 1 German, 2 Danish, 1 Italian, and 1 Spanish. The total receipts since October 27 are Fr. 7,034,993.40 and during that time 271 vessels transited the Canal, 126 being northward, and 145 southward bound.
A Domestic Tragedy.

A young native living at Bab Sidra, Alexandria, who had been divorced from his wife and whose attempts at resuming conjugal relations met with a non-possumus attitude from his spouse, clinched matters yesterday by stabbing her several times. The woman fell unconscious, but was not mortally wounded. Seeing his wife fall, however, the man imagined he had killed her and, filled with remorse, he drew a revolver and shot himself dead.
The Cairo Season.

Mena House Hotel will open for the season, under the management of Mr. A. Klinger, of the Nungovich Hotels Company,on November 1, remaining open for six months. The National Hotel opens on the same date, aud Mr. Bauer looks forward to having an excellent season. He has already received a large number of applications for rooms. The new dining room has now been quite completed, and looks very handsome. The Grand Hotel, Helouan, will also open on November 1.
Sequel to Fashn Tragedy.

Abdel Kader el Saadi, son of Lamloum Bey, head of the Fawaid tribe of Arabs,was acquitted last Saturday by the Native Court of Beni Souef of the charge of murdering two women. As a demonstration of delight at the termination of the case in his son's favor, Lamloum Bey encouraged his tribesmen to fire blank cartridges into the air. One gun, however, was charged with shot by mistake and,being let off accidentally, fatally wounded one man and inflicted serious injuries on two others.
Shop-breaking at Port Said.

At Port Said, on Friday night, two men were surprised in the act of breaking into a ship chandler’s in the Roe Hamdi. They then tried to make off with a barrow that was in the street outside, but wore prevented by the watchmen on the premises, whom they thereupon attacked with cudgels. The police appeared at this juncture, and managed to arrest one of the outlaws, who is a European. One of the watchmen was seriously wounded, and taken to hospital. The store was owned by a Mr. L. Feilla.
Hotel Robbery

Singularly awkward was the the predication in which a railway clerk, Raphael Effendi, and a cook, Hussein Aly, were placed when on the morrow of their arrival at the Hotel de France, Port Said, they woke to find their clothes and valuables had surreptitionsly disappeared from their bedrooms. The thief was also missing ; his name was not entered in the registry, and a process-verbal has been made out against the manager for this negligence. The fugitive is a native of Zagaz an evil character who had just concluded several months incarceration. The police are hot in pursuit of him.
FRENCH SUPPORT IMPOSSIBLE.
Paris, October 27.

The "Temps” publishes an article on Egypt- ian Nationalism. The Nationalists repudiated the ulterior design of reestablishing the rule of Turkey. Politically, they wish for the end of the English Occupation; morally, they would hasten the civilising evolution of Islam. Upon the first point the support of France is impossible; upon the second the Egyptian Press will recognise the Liberal tendencies of France concerning Mahomedanism in Algeria, Tunis, and the Sudan. ( Havas)
BELGIAN DIPLOMATIC AGENCY,
M. MASKENS TRANSFERRED.
A Havas telegram from Brussels announces that M. Maskens, Belgian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, has been appointed Belgian Minister at Athens. He will be succeeded in Cairo by M. le Gaissier.
PRINCE GEORGE’S CRUISE.
(From our Correspondent.)
Suez, Saturday.
The Danish steamer Burma, having on board H.R.H. Prince George of Greece and the Danish Princes, sailed from Suez early this morning en route to the Far East.
During the ship’s short stay at Suez, she was dressed with flags.
PRINCES NARROW ESCAPE.

Prince Mahmoud Pasha Hamdi, uncle of the Khedive, had a narrow escape while crossing the Upper Egypt railway line at Ghizah, on the Pyramids road, on Wednesday. By some oversight, the barrier was raised and several carriages had already crossed, when a goods train, northward bound, came up at full speed. Pascal Defranco, the chauffeur of the Prince, had sufficient presence of wind to draw up, and so avoided an accident, the result of which might have been no less fearful than that which befell the Prince’s cousin, Prince Ibrahim.
Maitre Carton de Wiart, motoring from Abbassieb, also had a close shave ; his motor passed within a few inches of the buffers of a locomotive.
THE RECENT STORM

The recent storm which passed over Egypt travelled from the West, visiting Malta, where on Friday week the lightning and thunder wore fearful. One church steeple was struck and injured, and several houses were damaged considerably. The bastions were struck in several places, and two policemen were dashed to the ground and stunned. There was no loss of human life. It was reported that 3 1/4 inches of rain fell during the night.
LOCAL WEDDING.

On Saturday, at the British Consulate, Alex­andria, before Mr. E. B. Gould, I S.O., Consul General, the civil marriage of Mr. Ernest Pittuk, Suez and Mies Gladys Williams took place, tbs contract being signed and witnessed by the bride’s brothers, Mr. R. S. and Mr. R. T. Williams. The party afterwards pro­ceeded to St. Mark’s Church, where the reli­gious ceremony took place, Rev. Longley officiating. In the church a good many mem­bers of the British community witnessed the interesting ceremony, after which the happy pair started through a shower of rose leaves and the blessings of their friends on their way to Cairo for their honeymoon.
EGYPTIANS IN AMERICA.

A Cincinnati contemporary says Seven young Egyptians arrived in Cincinnati yesterday to attend the Medical Department of the University of Cincinnati. They say that the . fame of the medical colleges in the Queen City is known the world over, and that they made the long journey from Cairo to attend here. They speak English freely, having studied it in the University of Cairo, but would not attend the medical university there because it is under Mohamedan rule. The strangers will return to Egypt as soon as they complete their studies here.

Another paper states:— Claiming that io their home country it is a sign of respect to wear the red fez they use for hats, seven Egyptians attending the medical department of the University of Cincinnati were surprised at a request to remove their caps in a local
restaurant.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Messageries Maritimes mail-boat Portugal through the Straits of Messina at
noon on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria tomorrow morning.
The Ellerman S.S. Arabian sailed from Malta on Saturday evening, and is due here on Wednesday with a general cargo.
NEW MINISTER APPOINTED.

Great surprise and interest will be excited, especially in native circles, by the news of the appointment of Saad Bey Zaghloul, judge of the Native Court of Appeal, to the posi­tion of Minuter of Public Instruction, vice Hussein Pasha Fakhry, who retains the port­folio of the Ministry of Public Works.

The new Minister is of Egyptian origin, with a trace of Bedouin blood, a National­ist of the type of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdo", and an efficient, honest, and energetic judge. His conduct at the Bar and on the Bench have won general respect for his abilities and admiration of his fairness and courage. A progressive and a patriot, firmly convinced that Egypt can only become a self-governing country when the Egyptians are morally and intellectually trained up to the European standard, he has had to bear much criticism from the conservative and Pan-Islamic elements, and even from Europeans, who considered him an unpractical idealist (a notion, by the way, which his legal success should have dispelled). His private life and his intellec­tual attainments alike fit him to bear the responsibilities of this new office with high credit.
Saad Bey Zaghloul was summoned by the Khedive on Saturday evening and came down to Alexandria yesterday, being granted a private audience by his Highness at Montazah Palace.
EGYPT AND ITALY.
SAVINGS BANK FACILITIES.

An agreement has been concluded between the Italian and Egyptian postal authorities whereby, on and after November 1, sums deposited in the Egyptian and Italian postal savings banks may be transferred from one country to the other. This will no doubt prove an immense boon to the very large number of Italian depositors in the local savings banks, who are continually remitting money to their native land.
WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.

Half of the land belonging to Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, between the French Agency and the company’s new buildings, has just been sold at a profitable price. The area of the land sold is 2,469 square metres. The land was originally purchased by Mr. Con­stantine Meimarachi, the managing director, from the Egyptian Estates at £15 per metre, and he passed it over to the company at the same price. Owing to this action of Mr. Meimarachi, the profit to the company now is about £26 per metre,which gives a total profit to the company of about £26,000 over this deal alone, leaving aside the other half of the land on which the company’s new building is. Mr. Meimarachi is to be congratulated on his foresight, as the profit of this transaction is solely due to him.
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Auiourdhui d midi et demie.)
Le marche a ouvert avec une animation extraordinaire, pour faiblir pen apres a la suite de realisations. Vers la fin, cependant, la fermete reprend le dessus et la cloture a lieu en hausse partielle.
Les transactions ont porte specialement sur l’Union Fonciere, le Credit Franco Egyptien, le Comptoir, les Estates, la Nile Land, la Delta Land, la Salt and Soda, la National Bank et la Behera.

Cette derniere beneficie d’une nouvella avance de L E. 3 a 45 1/2. L’Union Fonciere finit demandee a 6 1/2, apres avoir atteint un moment 6 5/8. Tres mouvementes au debut entre 2 9/32 et 2 11/32, les Estates reviennent. eu cloture a 2 1/4 vendeurs. La Delta Land flechit de 4 3/32 a 4 1/16, tandis que la Nile Land s'avance de 16 5/16 a 16 7/16.

Peu de mouvement sur les banques : l’Agri- cole s’avance de 9 3/4 a 9 13/16 ; l’obligation Credit Foncier remonte de 334 a 336 l’ancienne et de 271 a 271 1/2 la nouvelle; la Cassa di Seonto reactionne de 240 a 239 1/2, la banque d' Athenes de 148 a 116 1/2, le Banco di Roma de 113 a 112 et la Banque d’Orient de 133 3/4 a 133 1/2; le Credit Franco-Egyptien gagne 1/32 a 5 9/16 ; la National Bank est immobile a 27 5/16 acheteurs.
Les Tramways d’Alexandria reculent de 188 a 187 1/2. .
Par contre, lea Markets montent de 26,6 a 27, la Biere d’Alexandrie de 221 a 222, les Cotton Mills de 6 a 6/3, la Salt & Soda de 22/9 a 23/9 et l’Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 35 a 35/6.
De 18 1/2 les Nungovich Hotels reviennent a 18 7/16, le Trust de 1 15/32 a 1 13/32 et la Building Lands de 4 31/32 a 4 29/32.
